OLED , URL: /wiki/OLED: "Between 0.0001 and 0.00001 nits" "Sony claims an OLED contrast range of 1,000,000:1. When I asked how the contrast could be so high I was told that the surface is SO black the contrast is almost infinite. If the number representing the dark end of the contrast scale is nearly zero then dividing that number into the brightest value results in a very, very high contrast ratio."[6] (1) Pixels can reset to black nearly instantaneously, so black levels remain consistently as black as they can be.

CRT , URL: /wiki/Cathode-ray_tube: 8-bit per subpixel resolution; offers better resolution for grayscale[citation needed]
OLED , URL: /wiki/OLED: 8- to 10-bit per subpixel, with some HDR models capable of 12-bit per subpixel.[12]

LCD , URL: /wiki/Liquid-crystal_display: 1–8 ms typical (according to manufacturer data), older units could be as slow as 35 ms[15]
Plasma , URL: /wiki/Plasma_display: Typically less than 0.001 ms, as low as 0.00001 ms[13]
OLED , URL: /wiki/OLED: Estimates varying from under 0.01 ms to as low as 0.001 ms.[16][17]

CRT , URL: /wiki/Cathode-ray_tube: 60–85 fps typically, some CRTs can go even higher (200 fps at reduced resolution[18]); internally, display refreshed at input frame rate speed
LCD , URL: /wiki/Liquid-crystal_display: 60 fps typically, gaming monitors can do up to 360 fps; internally, display refreshed at up to 360 fps[19][20]
Plasma , URL: /wiki/Plasma_display: 60 fps typically, some can do 120 fps; internally, display refreshed at e.g. 480 or 600 fps[21]

CRT , URL: /wiki/Cathode-ray_tube: Perceptible on lower refresh rates (60 fps and below)[22]
Plasma , URL: /wiki/Plasma_display: Does not normally occur due to a high refresh rate higher than FPS[25]
Varies with brightness but usually higher than LCD[31][32][33][34]
OLED , URL: /wiki/OLED: Varies based on image brightness and color. For the majority of images it will consume 60–80% of the power of an LCD. OLED displays use 40% of the power of an LCD displaying an image that is primarily black as they lack the need for a backlight,[35] while OLED can use more than three times as much power to display a mostly white image compared to an LCD.[36]

CRT , URL: /wiki/Cathode-ray_tube: Sensitive to ambient magnetic fields, which can adversely affect convergence and color purity.
LCD , URL: /wiki/Liquid-crystal_display: Prone to malfunctions on both low (below −20 °C, −4 °F) or high (above 45 °C, 113 °F) temperatures[37]
Plasma , URL: /wiki/Plasma_display: High altitude pressure difference may cause poor function or buzzing noises[38]

OLED , URL: /wiki/OLED: No, control circuitry may emit radio interference

CRT , URL: /wiki/Cathode-ray_tube: Hazardous to repair or service due to high-voltage, requires skilled convergence calibration and adjustments for geographic location changes.[46] Glass display tube is evacuated and carries risk of implosion if improperly handled.
Plasma , URL: /wiki/Plasma_display: Screen itself cannot be repaired if the gas used to generate images leaks[49]

CRT , URL: /wiki/Cathode-ray_tube:
native resolution , URL: /wiki/Native_resolution
Display lag , URL: /wiki/Display_lag
LCD , URL: /wiki/Liquid-crystal_display: The LCD grid can mask effects of spatial and grayscale quantization, creating the illusion of higher image quality.[52] Is the cheapest display technology currently produced, with some entry-level models selling for less than $100.
Plasma , URL: /wiki/Plasma_display: Screen-door effects are more noticeable than LCD when up close, or on larger sizes.[53] New models are no longer produced.
OLED , URL: /wiki/OLED: Colored sub-pixels may age at different rates, leading to a color shift. Sensitive to UV light from direct sunlight. Is considered the highest quality but also the most expensive display technology currently produced, with products rarely being available for less than $1200.
